Authors: Benawa A., Gea A.A., Willyarto M.N.
Title: Improving teacher’s commitment by improving external factors
Affiliations: CBMKU Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Benawa, A., CBMKU Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Gea, A.A., CBMKU Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Willyarto, M.N., CBMKU Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: This article was written base on our research, which obtain the information that there is direct positive effect of organizational culture, leadership, work environment, and organization trust as the external factors on the organizational commitment. By quantitative approach our research used a survey method by structured interview with a sample of 75 teachers. The data collected were processed by path analyses. The result showed that the organizational commitment was effected directly positive by the external factors, i.e., organizational culture, leadership, work environment, and trust. The implication is the teacher’s organizational commitment can be increased by improving the organizational culture, leadership, work environment and trust as the external factors. © 2017 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Leadership; Organizational commitment; Organizational culture; Trust; Work environment
References: Colquitt, J.A., Lepine, J.A., Wesson, M.J., (2011) Organizational Behavior: Improving Performance and Commitment in the Workplace, 69, p. 66. , McGraw-Hill, New York; Robbins, S.P., Judge, T.A., (2011) Organizational Behavior, p. 145. , Prentice Hall, New Jersey; Colquitt, J.A., Lepine, J.A., Wesson, M.J., (2011) Organizational Behavior: Improving Performance and Commitment in the Workplace, pp. 557, 451, 219. , McGraw-Hill, New York; Nyhan, R.C., (1999) Review of Public Personnel Administration, 19, p. 58; Perry, R.W., (2004) Review of Public Personal Administration, 24, p. 133; Ingersoll, G.L., Kirsch, J.C., Merck, S.E., Lightfoot, J., (2000) Journal Nurse Administration, 30, p. 11; Williams, E.S., Rondeau, K.V., Francescutti, L.H., (2007) Leadership in Health Services, 20, p. 158; Slocum, J.W., Hellriegel, D., (2007) Principles of Organizational Behavior, South Western, p. 328; Canessa, E., Riolo, R.L., (2003) Computational and Mathematical Organization Theory, 9, p. 147; Lok, P., Crawford, J., (2004) Journal of Management Development, 23, p. 321; Walumbwa, F.O., Orwa, B., Wang, P., Lawler, J.J., (2005) Human Resource Development Quarterly, 16, p. 235; Yousef, D.A., (2000) Journal of Managerial Psychology, 15, p. 6; Avolio, B.J., Zhu, W., Koh, W., Bhatia, P., (2004) Journal of Organizational Behavior, 25, p. 951; McCormick, E.J., Tiffin, J., (2004) Industrial Psychology, p. 465. , Prentice Hall, New Jersey; Kürşad, Y., (2008) Journal of Applied Sciences, 8, p. 2293

Authors: Gea A.A., Tampubolon S.M., Lakonawa P.
Title: Developing positive multicultural attitudes in student organization
Authors with affiliations: Gea, A.A., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Tampubolon, S.M., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Lakonawa, P., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: The multicultural mindset and attitude have become compulsory requirements for the professionals in this globalized era of today. For that reason education should help develop students’ skills in this aspect. To portray how student organization fosters the skills this research article is conducted. Using the qualitative research method, it analyzes the management of multiculturalism at BINUS Industrial and Information Business Club (BIIBC). Through interviews, questionnaires and observations, the study will examine and explore how BIIBC manage and develop the multicultural attitude within the organization. © 2017 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Cultural diversity; Models of multiculturalism; Multicultural attitude; Multicultural management; Multiculturalism
References: Hartmann, D., Gerteis, J., (2005) Sociological Theory, 23, p. 2; Kapukaya, K., (2010) Journal of Cultural Studies, 8, p. 1; Maxwell, Y., (2011) Canadian Ethnic Studies, p. 43; Munusamy, V.P., (2008) International Management, p. 25; Naseem, M.A., (2011) Canadian Issues, p. 9; Sayles-Hannon, S.J., (2008) In Search of Multiculturalism: Uprooting ‘Whiteness’ in Curriculum Design and Pedagogical Strategies, 66p. , Texas Woman’s University; Song, S., (2005) The American Political Science Review, 99, p. 4; Suparlan, P., (2001) Kesetaraan Warga Dan Hak Budaya Komuniti Dalam Masyarakat Majemuk Indonesia, , Andalas University, Padang

Title: Neuro-research method: A synthesis between hermeneutics and positivism
Authors with affiliations: Fios, F., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Sasmoko, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Gea, A.A., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: In the history of philosophy, we know that hermeneutics and positivism are two main currents paradigms which have always contradicted in an effort to find the truth of science. Hermeneutics priority to the principle of interpretation of a text studied. While quantitative positivism path to get the truth based on the reality itself. Hermeneutics applying qualitative elements, while positivism applies quantitative elements in studied. The question is whether these two methods can be synthesized? Neuro research method assumed to reconcile between the hermeneutic perspective (qualitative) and positivism (quantitative). Neuro research done by taking three (3) main processes, namely: exploration research (qualitative), then explanatory research (quantitative) and finally confirmatory studies (quantitative). This method can be applied to search for scientific truth for the social sciences humanities. This paper is a philosophical reflection on neuro research method was being developed at several universities in Indonesia, especially at Bina Nusantara University of Jakarta. © 2016 American Scientific Publishers. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Hermeneutic; Mix method; Neuro-research; Positivism; Synthesis
References: Budi Hardiman, F., (2003) Melampaui Positivisme Dan Modernitas, 38p. , Diskursus Filosofis tentang Metode Ilmiah Dan Problem Modernitas, Kanisius, Yogyakarta; Borchert, D.M., (2006) Encyclopedia of Philosophy, 4, 334p. , Second edn., Thomson-Gale, Detroit; Authors: Gea A.A., Fios F., Manurung C.
Title: Ideal leader characters in Indonesia according to Megawati Soekarnoputri’s Perspective
Authors with affiliations: Gea, A.A., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11530, Indonesia; Fios, F., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11530, Indonesia; Manurung, C., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11530, Indonesia
Abstract: The 2014 was a crucial year for the political map of Indonesia. The people of Indonesia has elect a leader who will lead Indonesia for 5 years (2014–2019) through the democratic party elections. One important aspect in the general election that profiles the nation’s leader (president) who will lead this country. The leader of the nation should have a quality characters. The character of the leader is very important because it determines the fate of the nation and the development orientation. Ahead of the general election 2014, to highlight the various leaders revealed discourse suitable for Indonesia. One of the prominent discourse appears in the statement of Megawati Soekarnoputri (Chairman of the Indonesian Democratic Party of Struggle) were exposed in the Kompas Newspaper Edition January to February 2014. This study examines the statement of Megawati Soekarnoputri to find the view of Megawati about the right person to lead Indonesia five years to come. Using qualitative methods approaching to critical discourse analysis (CDA), researchers examined the perception of Megawati Sukarnoputri of characters matching the ideal leader to lead Indonesia. The study found 10 characters ideal leader according to Megawati Sukarnoputri in Indonesia. These findings provide an important contribution to the relevance of political educational leadership in Indonesia in order to prepare the younger generation of leaders in the future. © 2015 American Scientific Publishers.
References: Wetherell, M., (2001) Discourse as Data, , The Open University, Milton Keynes; Moustakes, C., (1994) Phenomenological Research Methods, 9p. , Sage Publication, California; Gadamer, H.G., (1976) Philosophical Hermeneutics, p. 513. , Editor and Translator by D.
